authors.name: J. K. Rowling
authors.description: Joanne "Jo" Rowling, OBE, FRSL, pen names J. K. Rowling and Robert Galbraith, is a British novelist, screenwriter and film producer best known as the author of the Harry Potter fantasy series.

authors.name: Brandon Sanderson
authors.description: Brandon Sanderson is an American fantasy and science fiction writer. He is best known for his Mistborn series and his work in finishing Robert Jordan's epic fantasy series The Wheel of Time.

authors.name: Bob Woodward
authors.description: Robert Upshur "Bob" Woodward is an American investigative journalist and non-fiction author. He has worked for The Washington Post since 1971 as a reporter and is now an associate editor of the Post.

authors.name: Siddhartha Mukherjee
authors.description: Siddhartha Mukherjee is an Indian-born American physician, scientist, and writer best known for his 2010 book, The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer, which was awarded the 2011 Pulitzer Prize for General Non-Fiction.
authors.alma_mater:
Stanford University
Magdalen College, Oxford
Harvard Medical School

authors.name: Patrick Rothfuss
authors.description: Patrick James Rothfuss is an American writer of epic fantasy. He is best known for his projected three-volume series The Kingkiller Chronicle.

authors.name: Robin Hobb
authors.description: Robin Hobb is a pseudonym of Margaret Astrid Lindholm Ogden, an American writer. She is best known for the books set in the Realm of the Elderlings, which started in 1995 with the publication of Assassin's Apprentice, the first book in the Farseer trilogy.

authors.name: Orson Scott Card
authors.description: Orson Scott Card is an American novelist, critic, public speaker, essayist and columnist. He writes in several genres but is known best for science fiction.
authors.alma_mater:
Brigham Young University
University of Utah (M.A.)
University of Notre Dame (1980s graduate student)

authors.born:
Isaak Ozimov
Between October 4, 1919 and January 2, 1920[1]
Petrovichi, Russian SFSR
authors.name: Isaac Asimov
authors.description: Isaac Asimov was an American author and professor of biochemistry at Boston University. He was known for his works of science fiction and popular science.

authors.name: Terry Pratchett
authors.description: Sir Terence David John "Terry" Pratchett, OBE was an English author of fantasy novels, especially comical works. He is best known for his Discworld series of 41 novels. Pratchett"s first novel, The Carpet People, was published in 1971.

authors.name: Douglas Adams
authors.description:
Douglas Noel Adams was an English author, scriptwriter, essayist, humorist, satirist and dramatist.
Adams is best known as the author of The Hitchhiker"s Guide to the Galaxy, which originated in 1978 as a BBC radio comedy before developing into a 'trilogy' of five books that sold more than 15 million copies in his lifetime and generated a television series, several stage plays, comics, a computer game, and in 2005 a feature film.

authors.name: Eoin Colfer
authors.description: Eoin Colfer is an Irish author of children's books. He worked as a primary school teacher before he became a full-time writer. He is best known for being the author of the Artemis Fowl series.

authors.name: Stephen King
authors.description: Stephen Edwin King is an American author of contemporary horror, supernatural fiction, suspense, science fiction, and fantasy. His books have sold more than 350 million copies, many of which have been adapted into feature films, miniseries, television shows, and comic books.

authors.name: Terry Goodkind
authors.description: Terry Goodkind is an American writer. He is known for the epic fantasy series The Sword of Truth as well as the contemporary suspense novel The Law of Nines, which has ties to his fantasy series.

authors.name: Robert Jordan
authors.description: James Oliver Rigney, Jr., better known by his pen name Robert Jordan, was an American author of epic fantasy. He is best known for the Wheel of Time series, which comprises 14 books and a prequel novel.

authors.name: Michael Jenkins Moynihan
authors.education:
University of Colorado
studied language and history
Portland State University
B.A. in German language
authors.description: Michael Jenkins Moynihan is an American journalist, publisher, and musician. He is best known for co-writing the book Lords of Chaos, about black metal.

authors.name: Lev Grossman
authors.education: Lexington High School, Harvard University, Yale University
authors.description: Lev Grossman is an American novelist and journalist, notably the author of the novels Warp, Codex, The Magicians, The Magician King, and The Magician's Land. He is a senior writer and book critic for TIME.

authors.name: Khaled Hosseini
authors.description: Khaled Hosseini is an Afghan-born American novelist and physician. After graduating from college, he worked as a doctor in California, an occupation that he likened to "an arranged marriage".

authors.name: Stieg Larsson
authors.description: Karl Stig-Erland "Stieg" Larsson was a Swedish journalist and writer. He is best known for writing the Millennium trilogy of crime novels, which were published posthumously and adapted as motion pictures.

authors.name: David Lagercrantz
authors.description: David Lagercrantz is a Swedish journalist and best-selling author, internationally known as the author of I am Zlatan Ibrahimovic and The Girl in the Spider’s Web, the fourth instalment in the Millennium series originated by Stieg Larsson.

authors.name: Harper Lee
authors.description: Nelle Harper Lee, better known by her pen name Harper Lee, was an American novelist widely known for To Kill a Mockingbird, published in 1960. Immediately successful, it won the 1961 Pulitzer Prize and has become a classic of modern American literature.

authors.name: Garth Nix
authors.description: Garth Richard Nix is an Australian writer who specialises in children's and young adult fantasy novels, notably the Old Kingdom, Seventh Tower and Keys to the Kingdom series.

authors.name: Anne Frank
authors.died:
February or March 1945 (aged 15)
Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, Lower Saxony, Germany
authors.description: Annelies Marie Frank was a German-born diarist and writer. One of the most discussed Jewish victims of the Holocaust, she gained fame posthumously following the publication of her diary, The Diary of a Young Girl, which documents her life in hiding from 1942 to 1944, during the German occupation of the Netherlands in World War II.

authors.name: Elie Wiesel
authors.description: Eliezer "Elie" Wiesel KBE was a Romanian-born American Jewish writer, professor, political activist, Nobel Laureate and Holocaust survivor.

authors.name: Oswald Spengler
authors.description: Oswald Arnold Gottfried Spengler was a German historian and philosopher of history whose interests included mathematics, science, and art. He is best known for his book The Decline of the West, published in 1918 and 1922, covering all of world history.
authors.alma_mater:
University of Munich
University of Berlin
University of Halle

authors.name: Jon Krakauer
authors.description: Jon Krakauer is an American writer and mountaineer, primarily known for his writings about the outdoors, especially mountain-climbing.

authors.name: Fyodor Dostoyevsky
authors.description: Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky, sometimes transliterated Dostoevsky, was a Russian novelist, short story writer, essayist, journalist and philosopher.

authors.name: Mallory Ortberg
authors.description: Mallory Ortberg is an American author, editor, and a co-founder of the feminist general interest site The Toast. She previously wrote for Gawker and the Hairpin, where she met Toast co-founder Nicole Cliffe.

authors.name: Ernest Hemingway
authors.description: Ernest Miller Hemingway was an American novelist, short story writer, and journalist. His economical and understated style had a strong influence on 20th-century fiction, while his life of adventure and his public image influenced later generations.

authors.name: Erik Larson (author)
authors.description: Erik Larson is an American journalist and author of nonfiction books. He has written a number of bestsellers, such as The Devil in the White City, about the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago and a series of murders by H. H.

authors.name: Amy Poehler
authors.description: Amy Poehler is an American actress, comedian, director, producer, voice artist and writer. After studying improv at Chicago's Second City and ImprovOlympic in the early 1990s, she went to New York City in 1996 to become part of the improvisational comedy troupe Upright Citizens Brigade.

authors.name: Sun Tzu
authors.description: Sun Tzu was a Chinese general, military strategist, and philosopher who lived in the Spring and Autumn period of ancient China.

authors.name: 14th Dalai Lama
authors.description: The 14th Dalai Lama /ˈdɑːlaɪ ˈlɑːmə/, /ˌdælaɪ ˈlɑːmə/ is the current Dalai Lama. Dalai Lamas are important monks of the Gelug school, the newest school of Tibetan Buddhism which is nominally headed by the Ganden Tripas.

authors.name: Walter Isaacson
authors.description: Walter Isaacson FRSA is an American writer and journalist. He is the President and CEO of the Aspen Institute, a nonpartisan educational and policy studies organization based in Washington, D.C.

authors.name: Jerzy Kosiński
authors.description: Jerzy Kosiński, born Józef Lewinkopf, was an award-winning Polish-American novelist and two-time President of the American Chapter of P.E.N., who wrote primarily in English.

authors.name: Gary Younge
authors.description: Gary Younge is a British journalist, author and broadcaster. He is a feature writer and columnist for The Guardian newspaper and writes a monthly column for The Nation, "Beneath the Radar".

authors.name: Rysa Walker
authors.description: Rysa Walker is the winner of the 2013 Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award and author of novels called Timebound, Time's Edge, and a novella entitled Time's Echo.

authors.name: R. D. Laing
authors.description: Ronald David Laing, usually cited as R. D. Laing, was a Scottish psychiatrist who wrote extensively on mental illness – in particular, the experience of psychosis.

authors.born:
Vladimir Vladimirovich Nabokov
22 April [O.S. 10 April] 1899a
Saint Petersburg, Russian Empire
authors.name: Vladimir Nabokov
authors.description: Vladimir Vladimirovich Nabokov was a Russian-American novelist. His first nine novels were in Russian, and he achieved international prominence after he began writing English prose.

authors.name: Oscar Wilde
authors.description: Oscar Fingal O'Flahertie Wills Wilde was an Irish playwright, novelist, essayist, and poet. After writing in different forms throughout the 1880s, he became one of London's most popular playwrights in the early 1890s.
authors.alma_mater:
Trinity College, Dublin
Magdalen College, Oxford

authors.name: Chinua Achebe
authors.description: Chinua Achebe was a Nigerian novelist, poet, professor, and critic. His first novel Things Fall Apart is also considered his magnum opus, and is the most widely read book in modern African literature.

authors.name: Maurice Sendak
authors.description: Maurice Bernard Sendak was an American illustrator and writer of children's books. He became widely known for his book Where the Wild Things Are, first published in 1963.
authors.alma_mater: Art Students League of New York

authors.name: Eric Carle
authors.description: Eric Carle is an American designer, illustrator, and writer of children's books. He is most famous for The Very Hungry Caterpillar, a picture book with few words that has been translated into more than 62 languages and sold more than 44 million copies.
authors.alma_mater:
Academy of Fine Arts Stuttgart
Academy of Fine Arts Vienna

authors.name: Margaret Wise Brown
authors.description: Margaret Wise Brown was an American writer of children's books, including the picture books Goodnight Moon and The Runaway Bunny, both illustrated by Clement Hurd.

authors.name: Mario Puzo
authors.description: Mario Gianluigi Puzo was an American author, screenwriter and journalist. He is known for his crime novels about the Mafia, most notably The Godfather, which he later co-adapted into a three-part film saga directed by Francis Ford Coppola.

authors.name: George Orwell
authors.description: Eric Arthur Blair, who used the pen name George Orwell, was an English novelist, essayist, journalist and critic. His work is marked by lucid prose, awareness of social injustice, opposition to totalitarianism, and outspoken support of democratic socialism.

authors.name: Anthony Burgess
authors.description: John Anthony Burgess Wilson, FRSL – who published under the pen name Anthony Burgess – was an English writer and composer. From relatively modest beginnings in a Catholic family in Manchester, he eventually became one of the best known English literary figures of the latter half of the twentieth century.

authors.name: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
authors.description: Antoine Marie Jean-Baptiste Roger, comte de Saint-Exupéry was a French writer, poet, aristocrat, journalist, and pioneering aviator. He became a laureate of several of France's highest literary awards and also won the U.S. National Book Award.

authors.name: F. Scott Fitzgerald
authors.description: Francis Scott Key Fitzgerald, known professionally as F. Scott Fitzgerald, was an American novelist and short story writer, whose works illustrate the Jazz Age. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest American writers of the 20th century. Fitzgerald is considered a member of the 'Lost Generation' of the 1920s.

authors.name: J. R. R. Tolkien
authors.description: John Ronald Reuel Tolkien CBE FRSL, known by his pen name J. R. R. Tolkien, was an English writer, poet, philologist, and university professor who is best known as the author of the classic high-fantasy works The Hobbit, The Lord of the Rings, and The Silmarillion.

authors.name: William Shakespeare
authors.description: William Shakespeare was an English poet, playwright, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world"s pre-eminent dramatist. He is often called England"s national poet, and the "Bard of Avon".

authors.name: Meg Cabot
authors.description: Meg Cabot is an American author of romantic and paranormal fiction for teens and adults and used to write under several pen names, but now writes exclusively under her real name.

authors.name: Markus Zusak
authors.description: Markus Frank Zusak is an Australian writer. He is best known for The Book Thief and The Messenger, two novels for young adults which have been international best-sellers.

authors.name: Shel Silverstein
authors.description: Sheldon Allan "Shel" Silverstein was an American poet, singer-songwriter, cartoonist, screenwriter, and author of children"s books. He styled himself as Uncle Shelby in some works. Translated into more than 30 languages, his books have sold over 20 million copies. He was the recipient of two Grammy Awards, as well as a Golden Globe and Academy Award nominee.

authors.name: Dr. Seuss
authors.description: Theodor Seuss Geisel was an American writer, cartoonist, animator, book publisher, and artist best known for authoring children's books under the pen name Dr. Seuss.

authors.name: Joshua Waitzkin
authors.description: Joshua Waitzkin is an American chess player, martial arts competitor, and author. As a child, he was recognized as a prodigy, and won the U.S. Junior Chess championship in 1993 and 1994. He is the only person to have won the National Primary, Elementary, Junior High School, High School, U.S. Cadet, and U.S. Junior Closed chess championships in his career. The movie Searching for Bobby Fischer is based on his early life.

authors.name: Tim Ferriss
authors.description: Timothy "Tim" Ferriss is an American author, entrepreneur and public speaker. He has written a number of self-help books which have appeared on the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and USA Today bestseller lists, starting with The 4-Hour Workweek.

authors.name: Max Brooks
authors.description: Maximillian Michael Brooks is an American horror author and screenwriter. He is the son of comedy filmmaker Mel Brooks and actress Anne Bancroft. Brooks's writing focuses on zombie stories. Brooks is also a television and voice-over actor.

authors.name: David Mitchell (comedian)
authors.description: David James Stuart Mitchell is a British comedian, actor and writer. He is half of the comedy duo Mitchell and Webb alongside Robert Webb. The duo starred in the Channel 4 sitcom Peep Show in which Mitchell plays Mark Corrigan.

authors.name: Malcolm Gladwell
authors.description: Malcolm Timothy Gladwell CM is an English-born Canadian journalist, author, and speaker. He has been a staff writer for The New Yorker since 1996.

authors.name: Steven Levitt
authors.description: Steven David "Steve" Levitt is an American economist known for his work in the field of crime, in particular on the link between legalized abortion and crime rates. Winner of the 2003 John Bates Clark Medal, he is currently the William B.

authors.name: Richard Rhodes
authors.description: Richard Lee Rhodes is an American historian, journalist and author of both fiction and non-fiction, including the Pulitzer Prize-winning The Making of the Atomic Bomb, and most recently, The Twilight of the Bombs.

authors.name: Charles Darwin
authors.description: Charles Robert Darwin, FRS FRGS FLS FZS was an English naturalist and geologist, best known for his contributions to the science of evolution.

authors.name: Stephen Hawking
authors.description: Stephen William Hawking, CH, CBE, FRS, FRSA is an English theoretical physicist, cosmologist, author and Director of Research at the Centre for Theoretical Cosmology within the University of Cambridge.
authors.alma_mater:
University College, Oxford (BA, 1962)
Trinity Hall, Cambridge (PhD, 1965)

authors.name: Bill Bryson
authors.description: William McGuire "Bill" Bryson OBE FRS is a best-selling Anglo-American author of books on travel, the English language, science, and other non-fiction topics.

authors.name: Karen Blixen
authors.description: Baroness Karen von Blixen-Finecke, née Karen Christenze Dinesen, was a Danish author, also known by the pen name Isak Dinesen, who wrote works in Danish, French and English. She also at times used the pen names Tania Blixen, Osceola, and Pierre Andrézel.

authors.name: Neil Gaiman
authors.description: Neil Richard MacKinnon Gaiman is an English author of short fiction, novels, comic books, graphic novels, audio theatre, and films.

authors.name: Steven Erikson
authors.description: Steven Erikson is the pseudonym of Steve Rune Lundin, a Canadian novelist, who was educated and trained as both an archaeologist and anthropologist.
